Riff Racer, what a game. To be honest, I did not expect it to be so good. This is one of those games that you put your music into and they generate a racing track, which fits the music. Even though it's in Early Access, it does its job better than other game of the same genre.Below the final verdict is the complete list of music that I've played for this review.Pros: Terrific surroundings (skyscrapers, spotlights, etc.) It does a really good job at converting the music into the track you are driving on. The drops are amazing, boost pickups are synchronised with the beats and even landings fit the music! Even though it's a racing game, I did not expect to see drifting in this game. It's awesome! There are jumps, flips, pickups, boosts and other stuff. There is a wide choice of vehicles that can be used in-game. Also, you can buy skins for them using "chips" you earn while playing. One of the main benefits (in my opinion): the graphic details are astonishing even on older computers. The game uses a low amount of system resources. There are no lags or disruptions in the music you're playing. Even if you crash, the music keeps going. This is not the case in Audiosurf, though. Even when you crash, use boost or in any way change your speed, the landscape is always synchronised with the current music. I don't know how they did it, but it's amazing. 												So, I fire up Riff Racer: Race Your Music!. What do I want to listen to? Riff Racer allows me to select anything from my MP3 files, so I pull up my MP3 list of songs and decide on Gojira’s latest album (Magma). I decide the title track will fit my mood perfectly. Ahead of me lies a neon track, spanning off into the horizon and far beyond what the naked eye can see. The music queues up, the song begins and my car starts accelerating. I deftly maneuver around an obstacle, and then, heart racing, I take a slide around a bend in the track, narrowing missing the rail as I get my car under control, hit a boost point, and go flying off of a jump, only to barely land on the next section of track. Before me waits an amusement park loop which I take at super boosted speeds. The music blaring, the track continues to form before me, the beat and dynamics of the song dictating where the game will take me next. A few minutes later, I cross the blue finish line, having finished with 100% synchronicity, good for quite a few points. I now hold first place on a track of my own creation.StoryThis isnt applicable. The story is really the track and how it responds to your musical selection, and how you respond to the track in turn.GraphicsThe graphics are quite cool looking. As mentioned in my intro, the tracks in Riff Racer are neon constructed out of and into nothingness. The horizon is ever your goal, and Riff Racer sends you there full throttle in a glowing world of bass, beats, and guitar (or whatever makes up the whole of the songs you select). To an extent, Riff Racer’s graphics are minimal, and yet you cant help but draw similarities to games like Tron, albeit beefed up and modernized.Overall, the graphics in Riff Racer aren’t mind blowing, but they do look really cool. I would give them an 8 out of 10GameplayThis is where Riff Racer truly shines. As a game that creates your experience around the music you select, Riff Racer does an exceptional job of being a dynamic, time and points based solo racing game. You can never see very far ahead, and so you will be constantly reacting to the world as Riff Racer shifts and creates the track based on the dynamic of the music.There are loops, jumps, obstacles, boosts, and plenty of twists and turns that offer opportunities to not only race full throttle, but also to get your drift on. My own best drift was right at 16 beats. Jumps are also timed, and you score more points based on how many beats your jump is good for. Depending on the angle of release on your jumps, you might also spin in the air, which counts as a trick that also garners you more points. Additionally, any special moves help to fill up your boost meter.Your boost meter is an essential part of Riff Racer. Basically, boosting allows you to stay ahead of the beats, which is your ultimate goal. You want to at the very least try to stay with the first beat at all times, but getting ahead of it will net you even more points. In addition to tricks, there are also coins and boxes all along the track that will also help fill your boost meter. Finally, there are also boosts along the track as well. The more you stay in boost mode, the more points you will earn. Points will allow you to rise in level, which will earn you bonus coins.Speaking of coins, you will earn those in each track by running over actual coins and boxes, by creating a track yourself (which, in Riff Racer, means you were the first to drive a track with any given song), by beating existing top 5 scores, and so on. You can use the coins to buy different cars and different skins for said cars. There is a notable difference in the various cars. The skins are just cosmetic.The controls are tight and fully responsive. Any time you are out of control in Riff Racer, it is because you over compensated, generally as a reaction to having to make some split second decisions. You can of course play the same track over and over, so once a track for a song has been created, it will always remain the same, and you can memorize the twists and turns in hopes of getting better scores.Riff Racer does what it needs to do perfectly. I give gameplay a 10 out of 10.SoundThe sound is always 100% in your hands in Riff Racer, as it is always determined by your own musical preference. The music playing is always your own choice, and that is 100% the in game sound.So, this is an easy 10 out of 10 as well. It is exactly what you make of it. You are 100% in control of what you hear.VerdictAs a music powered game, Riff Racer shines in every way. Played for hours at a time or a few songs at a time, Riff Racer keeps on giving and giving. You wont ever really tire of the experience Riff Racer provides, and Riff Racer is a game you will continue playing 5 or even 10 years from now. This is what I would consider a must own for any music and/or driving fans out there. Good times will be had aplenty.

												I was hesitating on this one since a lot of rhythm type games that generate tracks from user audio files feel kinda bland or else they have the problem of only being fun if you are using EDM tracks with heavy, distinctive beats. I was watching some trailers as well and was hesitating because I couldn't really discern what the game was doing with the tracks that would make them truly feel like you were playing the song.After spending just a short amount of time with it, it's winning me over very fast. It's called Riff Racer, which suggests guitar riffs, which suggests it should be fun with rock music, whereas a lot of music/rhythm games that procedurally generate tracks are not super good with rock tracks. I was super impressed to discover that playing rock tracks in this game feels very satisfying and the game can specifically detect if you are a playing a rock/metal track.As I was playing these rock songs, which don't have the heavy, distinctive beats that EDM tracks have, I kinda started to warm up to the things the game was doing to make you feel like you were playing the song. It was less about individual beats and more about the energy of the song. Placing a speed boost right when the chorus takes off. Dropping a huge ramp right when the song tears into a guitar solo. Shifting the lighting and colors to fiery hot as the song picks up speed and volume. Where Riff Racer lacks at emphasizing the individual beats of a song, it seems to excel at getting the visceral energy of a song just right. Of course I'd advise you to mostly pick out a songs that suit a game about hitting ramps in a fast car.The game has great controller support and the controls are fantastic. The driving feels almost as good as games like Mario Kart or Sonic All-Star Racing Transformed. The drifting takes a bit of getting used to, but its starts to make more sense the more you practice it.It's an arcade racer, so it's all about racking up points. Unlike other rhythm games, which focus on hitting the good objects and dodging the bad objects, Riff Racer does something slightly different. Hitting the good objects instead builds up a boost meter that you can use to trigger a manual boost (in addition to free boosts lying on the track). In order to get the most points, you need to go as fast as possible for as long as possible, hit collectibles, hit ramps (especially at an angle so that you can spiral jump for extra points), and execute long drifts around sharp corners. The faster and fancier you drive without falling off the track, flipping the car, or crashing into things, the more points you'll rack up. It's not just about hitting those beats (although it's that too); it's also about kicking butts.And of course there are global leaderboards, friend leaderboards, personal best, etc. The game comes with a bunch of songs bundled in, and you can use your own. You also gain points for racing tracks, and those points let you unlock new cars and paint jobs. The new cars and paint jobs are merely cosmetic, but it gives you something to work toward if you need that kind of motivation.The only downside to the game is that once you put 4 or 5 hours into it, race all of your favorite rock tracks, then you've pretty much seen the whole tour. You can still go back and score attack, but you're basically racing time trial on tracks that---while very fun---are largely similar, so it starts to get a little samey after a while.Rating the game on the scale below, I give it a hearty 6:7) A classic, essential, and/or must-buy game that is worth full price.6) A good game that is worth the full price.5) A pretty good game worth checking out--especially if discounted.4) A fairly good game, but I'd recommend buying it discounted.3) Not great, but a few redeeming qualities. Only buy if heavily discounted.2) Only worth checking out if you are dangerously curious.1) Avoid at all costs.

								Drive Any Track is a point to point racer that generates tracks based of your own music collection. While it sits in the same genre as games like Audiosurf, adding the cars with amazing drift handling really allows DAT to hold it's own. Not just a decent music generated game but one of the better arcade racers I've played in some time. Highly addictive and upon first play I was mesmerized by my screen for hours. The King is dead, long live the King. 


YouTube™ Video:  

			Views: 0		



Gameplay is simple, select a song, choose your car and burn rubber. Tracks are all given a star rating which dictate their difficulty and harder levels generally contained more obstacles and tighter turns.  Provided the song includes an id3 tag your score also gets uploaded to both local and global leaderboards. Tried a wide range of genres from classical through to chiptune and overall music generation was not only quick but produced some wonderful results.  Faster music had more jumps and loops while slower music seemed much more drift based.While there is still plenty to add in future (real-time lighting, skyboxes etc), Graphically speaking it already looks quite tron-like and beautiful. Currently in-game options were slim to none but given the minimalistic nature of the game I would hazard a guess it should run very well on a wide range of systems. Didn't skip a beat scaling up to 4k+ on a single 970. Something that did seem to be missing was a bunch of default music tracks which was a little unfortunate as I'm sure it would help with the competitive side of the game.Most of the features I would like to see included in future are already planned. Such as further control of stunts, improved tracking of stats and additional game modes, cars and environments. With that said DAT contains 12 standard cars (+2 secret), decent selection of liveries and enough change of environment and colour schemes that it stays fresh. The games few downsides like sometimes being stuck on your roof following a dodgy jump, or hurtling round a corner into a badly placed wall are easily outweighed by all the upsides.Overall if you're a fan of music based games or arcade racers such as Ridge Racer, RUSH, Burnout, Daytona or Outrun. DAT is well worth your weekly allowance and has got my stamp of approval. Cheers folks, now back to racing. :]

I'm assuming this is how they keep track of the leaderboard scores. If you have music without a tag you can always get something like MP3Info, a great utility that adds ID3 tags and customizing to files. All in all I would say this game has great potential and recommend it to anyone who loves driving games and music.

Riff RacerDeveloper: FOAM EntertainmentPublisher: FOAM EntertainmentIntroduction==========It's not often that I take interest in a game that even remotely resembles a racing game. However, Riff Racer is one of the extremely rare exceptions. Using your own music (or the included bundle of 25 songs) to generate racetracks, Riff Racer has you racing the music itself to earn points and coins. Your experience depends entirely on YOU and what music you load up into the game.Gameplay==========Riff Racer creates racetracks based on the songs in your music library. When you boot up the game you can direct the game to any folder on your PC with music in it and have it generate a special track specific to that song. All the different verses, choruses, drops, and more are styled to the music you load and become checkpoints.  Even the car you drive shares some characteristics of the music. The point of the game is to stay in time with the music and score as many points as you can. Staying in sync offers a 4x modifier, while being ahead offers a 10x modifier. If you fall behind, either by not using boosts or hitting obstacles, your modifier drops until you can catch back up with the music. Each track you load has a 1 to 5 star rating. The more stars, the more obstacles you'll face on the track. As you race on each track, you'll run into barriers, jumps, and pits that may impede you. There's also these small white cubes that fill up your boost meter. Collect 10 of these to get a boost at the press of a button. There's also coins to collect that are used to buy different cars and paint jobs for them. The points you earn go towards increasing your Driver Level. All this does, as far as I know, is show how much you've played the game. I've not seen or found any benefit to having a higher Driver Level.Graphics==========This game is pretty psychadelic. Sounds and colors everywhere, just blaring and blinking in time with the music. Mostly various shades of red and yellow, but it honestly looks pretty awesome. The backgrounds look pretty cool, as well as the buildings and structures you'll ride past. A small detail I noticed that's probably really obvious is that your modifier and your boost meter are shown on the back of your car. As your modifier goes up, your car will crackle with energy.Sound and Music==========The music depends on you. Play using your favorite songs for maximum enjoyment! I like video game music, so the vast majority of the songs I played are from some of my favorite video games. The gameplay demo videos below feature a Mega Man X remix and a track from Ys VI.Performance==========Riff Racer ran nigh perfectly on my custom rig. No FPS drops, played at 60+ FPS at nearly all times (dropping ever so slightly during Super Sync and Boosting), and no stuttering. I played mostly with my controller, but it's easy enough to play with a keyboard if you don't have a controller. You just have to steer and hit the boost key...simple enough right?Final Thoughts==========This is an awesome racer, even moreso if you play with your favorite tracks! Pretty much anyone can enjoy Riff Racer. You can tailor the game to your liking with different songs and car customization. If you get the chance to buy this game, I urge you to pick it up...especially if it's on sale.Gameplay Demo==========

												This is a fun, inventive, and interesting way to enjoy your music. If you like music and you like gaming, buy this.However, I want to address some concerns that negative reviews bring up:1) To those who say the game is too easy, I must insist you post higher scores than me on the same songs. This is why a leaderboard system exists. I will happily send you an mp3 gift of any song of your choosing, and then we can decide together if the game is too easy for you.2) I disagree that the specific song doesn't affect the track or gameplay significantly. The music isn't merely "background." In my experience, a song's crescendos, breakdowns, drops, and even minor variations result in loops, jumps, curves, and other set pieces. I can't imagine how one could miss this connection, but everyone is entitled their experience. Maybe my music is just more fun to drive.3) It's true that there isn't a ton of "unlockable" content. How could there be? This game is limited only by your music library. Yes, you can unlock new cars that only differ in appearance, and that's all there is to it. Would you really want the devs to artificially limit the manuverability of your car at the outset just to give you a false sense of progression?One of the most popular rhythm games of all time, Dance Dance Revolution, contained unlocks. What did they give you? New songs, new characters. This game gives you all of the songs in the world as tracks, but you can purchase a handful of cosmetic upgrades with the coins you collect from racing. It's not intended to be a deep experience nor should it be.4) If you don't have a gamepad, don't buy a racing game  on PC and expect keyboard buttons to have the same degree of control as an analog stick. That's the entire point of analog sticks.Honestly, I don't know what some people were expecting when they bought this. It's a racing game that builds racing tracks from your music. No, it's not <INSERT RHYTHM GAME HERE>. That's the point of being a new, different game.

												Riff Racer, previously called Drive Any Track, is basically Audiosurf without the match-3 puzzles. You load up a song from your hard drive, and the game generates a unique track for you to drive through, letting you compete for high scores with anyone else who's played the same track. The controls and presentation are simply sublime. Racing feels like F-Zero with its high speeds and crazy jumps; you really have to pay attention to the shape of the upcoming track if you don't want to wipe out. The smooth animation and futuristic visual style is wickedly awesome as well.Your score is mostly based on the stunts you perform; you get points for the length of each jump, double points for performing a mid-air roll, points for drifting around corners, and points for collecting crates. You lose points for hitting barriers, falling off the track, or flipping the car over. Additionally, if you start falling behind the song, your multiplier will diminish, and if you boost ahead of the song, you’ll get awarded with a whopping 10x multiplier. You can’t stay ahead of the song forever, so you’ll have to use your boosts strategically, not unlike star power in Guitar Hero games. Also interesting is that drifting won’t award points unless you’re actually driving around a corner – no fish-tailing exploits allowed.Although there's only a half-dozen game elements such as jump pads, boost pads, and collectables, the game succeeds in making every track feel like a unique experience – if you’re competing for a high score, you'll find that each track has its own distinct personality traits that you'll have to learn intimately. The track generator also takes some reasonable precautions to make sure you can see obstacles coming -- for instance, it zooms out the camera on loop-de-loops if there are barriers on the track, and it doesn't place barriers right after the peak of a hill. It demonstrates some impressive attention to detail, and makes casual play surprisingly relaxing and cathartic. There are exceptions, of course; you're bound to run into some surprising jumps and tricky turns, but half the fun of these kinds of games is memorizing your favorite tracks so that you can outscore the competition with the help of foresight. There's no difficulty toggle. However, some songs will be harder than others, denoted with a difficulty rating from one to five stars. If you want to find the most difficult songs, you'll have to hunt for them.The coolest feature of the game is being able to race against ghosts of other players. Oddly, the game doesn’t actually involve much “racing”; the only thing that matters is score, not your position on the track. Also weird is how you can’t race against any ghost you want, but only a predetermined list of 1-4 people who have beaten your high score (unless you hold the world record on a game, in which case you’ll be able to race against your own ghost and the ghost of the 2nd place holder).I give Riff Racer 8.8 / 10. This tops Beat Hazard as my favorite "media player" game to date. My only gripes have to do with some elements of the GUI; I wish the song selector were better, I wish you’d have more options of ghosts to race against. I wish you could see your boost meter and the ghost's score on the HUD without having to look at the cars themselves. It also wouldn’t hurt to see a few more game elements added to races. But overall, it fantastically does what these types of games are supposed to do: make you feel like you’re really getting into your favorite music. The final achievement is quite grindy, but I actually don’t mind, since I can see myself playing this game for a very long time. Well done. I'm not a big fan of Early Access myself, but you can mark this down as an Early Access success story.

								As a Fan of Beat Hazard (Another Music Based Game) I saw this game and had to give it a try, I have almost 3 hours of gameplay into DAT, theses are my thoughts...   Gameplay  The Gameplay consists of you racing on custom tracks, hitting jumps, drifting around corners and avoiding barriers that slow you down while you try to stay in sync with your song, fall behind can result in you getting out of sync and losing the chance of getting a 100% synchronization on the song you are playing. There are currently 3 things I noticed you collect as you race, that is a 10 tokens (the currency), boxes that fill your boost and give you additional points to your total point score and a separate boosters icon that gives you a boost as soon as you touch it, keep in mind that this booster icon doesn't take away the progress of you filling your boost from you collecting the boxes, it is its own separate boost. This makes me think of the midnight club la's slipstreaming, you can build up the slipstreaming and use it, that way you don't use a nitrous bar, but you still get a boost. The Performance Optimization  is solid, constant 60 fps through gameplay with i5 3570k and gtx 760, The Recommended Requirements are pretty low, and I am impressed by that. A Intel Core 2 Duo and a Geforce 8000 series are pretty old components to run a game like this. But this makes this game playable for more people, so that is a good thing.  Song difficulty Rating System  needs some work I think, for example I played a song by the uk power metal/speed metal band "Dragonforce" and these guys make a bunch of songs with intense guitars solos, and their tempo of their songs are just fast and the game only rated this Dragonforce Song a 1 star out of 5 star and then I played the Nickelback song "When We Stand Together" and apparently that song is rated 5/5, so I don't know how it's rating system works, it must work in a way that I don't understand or it's just not very accurate in this Alpha build of DAT . 												Must be the music I like, since even the slow music sometimes throws me off the track with ramp after ramp after ramp.  That being said ...This is a great game.  It's quite enjoyable to run the tracks trying to get a decent score while listening to music you enjoy.Most of my music is two stars, with a few three stars, and I've had a few pop up as four stars.  I've yet to see a five star song from my music ...  Maybe I should be careful what I ask for, as four star songs are pretty wild!The way you get points is by doing stunts.  You keep ahead of the first bar for maximum points.  Just driving doesn't get you anything, although you can use periods where you need to just drive to collect coins (for buying different cars and skins) and boost pack thingies (that you can use to activate your own boost whenever you want ... provided you've collected enough of them).You always take about the same amount of time to make it through the track, so to get points you do stunts.  You run over ramps, getting as much air time as possible.  To get more points, you hit the ramps so the car spins ... but this comes with a number of issues that really justifies the extra score.  For instance, if you hit the ramp wrong, it's possible to land on your roof, or be flung from the map altogether!  So be very very very careful jumping, especially if you plan on doing the high scoring spins!You also get points by drifting.  I suppose this can be abused, but whenever I've used drifting unnecessarily, I've always bounced off the walls.  Great way to fall behind, thus losing points!When you use the boost, it helps you get caught up, or you can use it just before a series of jumps to get ahead of the bar, increasing your point yield.  I'm the sort who tries to get more bang for my buck, so I always try to optimize when I use it.  But I rarely play the same track twice in a row, so it's always something of a gamble for me.If you play the same track over a few times to get the highest score you can, you won't have to wait for it to rebuild the track.  But if you go to another track, then come back to the first one, you'll have to wait for it to be rebuilt.  There's a "tip" that says that "you only have to wait the first time you play the track," but this is not entirely true.  It is only true if you play the track repeatedly, a few times in a row.Also, there are barriers on the road.  If bouncing off the walls, landing upside down after a trick jump, or flying clean off the road, aren't enough reasons to set you back, they stuck barriers on the road that will slow you down quite a bit.  Since you need to keep ahead of the first line to optimize your scoring, this can be quite a problem!You also lose points for every barrier you hit, so it's a good idea to avoid them for more than one reason.It can play m4a files, but not aac files.  Not a terribly large issue, just something to be aware of.  I do not know what other files it can play, as my library seems to be a mix of m4a and aac files.On difficulty:1 star - Very casual.  I think I've seen only one or two of these songs.  Maybe the Beehtoven one I played was one?  I don't recall.2 star - Casual.  This is where most of my music lands.  It actually has quite a diverse range of difficulty in this range.3 star - Normal.  You really have to start using all the tools it gives you to keep up here.  It can sometimes be pretty wild.4 star - Hard.  It's beginning to get wild here.  I've had about half a dozen of my tracks come up like this.  It leaves me crying with laughter at every surprise twist and turn it gives me, and it's hard to make normal jumps ... let alone the high point yield twisters, here!5 star - Insanity?  I've yet to see a song this hard, but I'm pretty sure most people would be falling off the track quite a bit here.  The maps may even be nearly unplayable!I generally listen to Indie music.  I look at the top tracks, and I don't see anything I actually have in my library on them, so I guess I can not race against the "most popular" track leaders.  In point of fact, it's pretty rare for me to play a track anyone else has played, so maybe I have it a bit easier than most people who play the game getting coins.

The game allows you to race on tracks that are designed around music chosen. You can select either music from the game or from your own music files you may have on your computer. Whenever you choose a song, a track is genreated based on the high/low pitches in music, use of cymbals or high-hats or where the bass might drop. While the game is able to generate these levels fairly well, for the most part I would experince the loud cresendo of a song while racing down a mostly empty stretch of road before the next ramo would appear several beats too late. That being said, the satisfaction of landing a jump off a ramp in time with a song beat is something that just feels undenaibly good.What the Game doesn't do so well...Remember when I said I had little experince with driving games earlier, with that in mind I personally distaste how the cars handle. Bearing in mind I'm playing on keyboard and mouse, the cars always seem to turn either too much or to little. I might try to turn around a bend but try and avoid on oncoming  barrier only to overcorrect the turn and smash into the wall. And drifting...Maybe it's just because I can't drift for ♥♥♥♥ but any attempt made only ever seems to result in collision with a wall whether I inteded to or not.Also, you know how peveryone who played Mario Kart pretty much hated playing Rainbow Road, well the same flaws can be seen here. At any given ramp, should it be approached at too steep an angle because you overcorrected, you will fall off the ramp entirely and slowly spawn back onto the track. While I wouldn't mind on any other racing game, the use of twisting roads and ramps meaning it occurs more often than I would like.With all that being said, I would say that while this game is probably not for me, I do think this is worth the discounted £8.24 price I paid to race against any of my music(None of which the game needs to liecence). The use of MEGA is something I appreaciate but I wish it was used in a more traditional Rthymn game rather than a less predictable arcade style racing game.Hopefully I may findone in the future.The game is good on the eyes and ears but feels too off for me.  If you enjoy arcade style racing games, you'll probably like this more than I will. Hope you enjoy.

 My Honest Review: Drive Any Track - 15/07/08
IntroI've always been fascinated by games that take audio/music and create unique tracks based on the highs and lows of songs. Audiosurf and its sequel have been long-time favorites for me. However, there was always something missing. There isn't a large amount of control you can give as you glide across a track to your favorite music.That's where Drive Any Track comes in. It improves upon that concept by giving you much more control over what you do on that track. You see that sharp turn over there? Yeeeeaaaaah... you can friggin' drift around that like a pro racer. What about that jump? Evil Knievel that as you sing along to the song. You have more control over how you literally drive the song.GameplayThe gameplay is a mixture of avoiding obstacles, collecting boxes for points/boost, collecting tokens for in-game customization, jumping off ramps (and landing them) all while staying in sync with the song you are playing. If you hit a barricade? You're going to lose some speed and possibly lose sync. Fail a jump? You might as well restart if you want that 100% bonus.As you finish songs to completion, you are given a place on the leaderboard for that song. If you were the first one to play that song, you are credited with being the track creator. Additionally, you are given XP for completing the song, which levels you up (which unlocks cars). The tokens you gathered throughout the songs can be used to buy paint-jobs for the cars you own.The game is essentially simple, which is to be expected of Early Access. Hopefully the developer adds some more game modes and spices up track generation.  Graphics/Sounds/Controls The game has simple graphics that allow the game to be played on a majority of low-end computers. The game is more focused on using simple, abstract and vibrant colors and lights to give the game more of an arcade-y feel that allows the game to portray different genres. I have not run into any performance issues as of yet.Sounds are entirely based on the quality of the audio file you are using. I recommend using the highest quality file to ensure the best listening pleasure.I have not used anything other than a keyboard for this game, so my experience in controllers or gamepads is non-existent. I can say that the games controls are simple and easy to learn. Playing on the keyboard is very useable as well. No need for controllers. Replayability The game's replayability is entirely dependant on the size of your music library. However, there are some problems where some songs will be given the wrong difficulty. Also, while every song has a unique track, it may get monotonous. The lack of different modes leave things to be desired. Overall The game is really good, it has massive potential. We just need some more modes to spice things up and increase replayability.+Very Enjoyable+Replayability based on music library+Simple graphics that fit the game+Addicting+Has a lot of potential+Leaderboard+Levels/Progress is recorded+Not many glitches/bugs+Steam Cloud+Developer IS ALIVE!/ Not that much customization (may change)/ Level cap prevents progress past 20 (may change)/ Track algorithm sometimes label songs incorrectly and give incorrect difficulties-Lack of variety in obstacles and jumps-Graphic options consist of only changing resolution-I suck at making reviews

								So, after a few tracks, heres a little First Look review of DATOn first glance you might say that this game seems a lot like audiosurf, just with an actual car instead of a polygonal glider.And Mono Mode only.Well, let me tell you - its not. While audiosurf is pretty much always straight ahead on 3 lanes, this right here is an actual racing game.Now, steering-wise the game is as simple as it gets. Left and right steer, Brake and gas arent needed, that does the game for you, CTRL is a handbrake for drifting and Space activates a Boost. Thats it.Your goal is to run a racetrack made from one of your songs and rack up as high of a score as you can. To do that you have to "stay in Sync" as the game tells you.Before you runs a visible line, thats where the track is right now on the race track. YOu can stay in a measure of 4 bars behind it to be in Synch and get the optimal amount of points for your tricks. if you fall more than 4 bars behind, you lose a multiplicator until you are at least 7 bars behind, where the game will set you back on track (with a respawn phase where you dont get any points. same for when you fly off the track)If you manage to overtake the Synch line, you enter a Supersynched mode where you amass more points but your speed and boost is slightly dampened, so you cant stay up there forever.Now, to get said points you just have to drive (a few points each measure of 4 beats), Jump (either by ramps on the track or by gaps in the track itself) Roll (same as jump - slightly tilted ramps or after Corkscrew Boosts) and Drift (by Using CTRL). After finishing a track you get some Boni depending on how good your driving was.Now what do I think? As someone who is pretty much terrible at racing games, I must say it is fun, plays pretty simple and even on Songs rated 4 Stars (out of 5) I managed to stay "in Sync" 60% of the time. Control is responsive, riding your tracks and experiencing your music completely different (again) feels nice and the Ghosting Modes (Race the world leader, the best ranked friend or a recommended random driver for a track) are fun too. Also, the mechanic of "discovering" tracks, by being the first player worldwide who has ever played that song gives the game a nice way of saying "Good job that you listen to different music!" However, Songs have to be IDE3 taggedto be accepted as discovered.As much as I like the game, It does have some flaws - sometimes the levels are built pretty counterproductive - like you get a boost into a long jump onto a sharp turn or you corkscrew a good 20 meters left to the track, sometimes when you resync you getdropped into a hole or a wall and lose more time and progress and its not really appearent weather or not you are drifting or if a drift has ended or has been aborted somehow. But since this game is early Acces as of now, it has room upwards.Not that it isnt far up alreadyIf you like racing games and you love music, this right here is a good buy.EDIT: Oh yeah - another little beef I have with this game - it does not save after a track, so when the game unexpectedly crashed I found myself short of the spoils of the previous 6 or 7 races.

												JANUARY 2017 UPDATED OPINION... (original review below this one)After coming back to this game after my initial purchase, I can say -some- of what I wrote in my original review might have sounded harsh. Most of the negatives still stand, but I feel this game is more of a "hmm, it's ok" than a downright "no". I have to say that "listening to your favorite music while driving some random track" is probably how I feel about it. Having a score to beat for one of my favourite bands (SCANDAL) has finally allowed me to appreciate this game more - even if the other guy has totally obliterated any chance I have of getting the best score.I still feel this game would be better if music packs were available to purchase - there is a lot of indie stuff out there, and I'm sure paid DLC would go a good way to making this game "bigger". Again, what I originally said in my original review still stands for the most part.END OF NEW OPINION. OLD REVIEW BELOW.Tl;DR - Stay away if you're expecting either a good racing game or good music game - this is neither!Got sucked in to buying this game, expecting more of a rhythm based game, than a "randomly" generated track to play from the song I selected. Unfortunately, it's neither a good racing game, nor is it a good music game: you are literally just racing with music in the background, and for most of the songs you try, the track will be fairly unexciting.Pros:• Select any mp3 song from your computer to generate a track• Trippy race-tracks• The cars all handle differentlyCons:• Very small selection of songs to choose from in-game - no songs I've heard of. This begs the question - did I just pay for a song to race-track generator? If so, I am disappointed.• Lacks any sort of story, and no proper levelling system, so it doesn't keep you wanting to play more; the only reason to keep playing more is to unlock more cars and paintjobs.• You're playing a race-track which has no real "rhythm" aspect to the game - it's all about doing drifts, keeping speed up, and not hitting walls or obstacles. Take away the music, and you'll realise you're just playing a lack-lustre race - the music only dictates the generation and "speed" of the level, not anything else.• The average song you will throw at the game will usually generate a rather boring track, I've found some of the weirder songs to generate better tracks. For example, I tried "Cherry Bomb" from Silent Siren, which created a challenging track, but then used a song from F-777 - Chinese Dance Machine, which created a rather tame, boring track. There doesn't seem to be a clear method to how a good race track gets generated.• No real feeling of accomplishment, as it's not like you can directly challenge others to beat your score unless they also have the same song (requires friends who also have this game), and you can't challenge a persons song directly either, you have to link your song first, there is no way to search for songs already played by others.The main thing that has gotten me to keep playing is the experimenting of throwing different songs at this to see how complex I can make the race track, and because I'm a bit of an acheivement hunter, I'll be "grinding" to get those cars and acheivements as well.Verdict: A drag to play, grinding for acheivements, no sense of competition/accomplishment. Like I mentioned, it's basically a race track generator without the real fun of a good racing game. Basically boils down to a zen-game in a way because of it. Not recommended unless the devs pull finger and integrate some sort of challenges that people can strive for, to give them reason to keep playing.

												I absoloutely adore this game.Its exactly what it says on the tin, Wipeout meets Audiosurf.But its a satisfying marriage that sometimes has moments that even best its lovely parents.PROS- Tight controls and physics, even in midair. If you fall to your doom it feels like your fault (usually :p).- Simple score system that has lots of aspects to it. When to boost? When to jump and when to go off those flips? When to start drifting for the longest drift? Little things can go a long way when going for highscores.- Unlockables. Its a little thing, but I always love unlockables. Gives you more reason to play beyond mechanical reasons (which the game does wonderfully mind you)- Nice, (generally) cohesive graphics that can run on any ol toaster like mine :)- You can sort of snake with practice. Givin' me the GX goosebumps ooh.- Ghosts are very well done and racing them gives a good competetive feel.CONS- Gui is servicable but text and buttons are too large. Text doesn't scroll when selecting new tracks so if a song has a long album/artist combination you can't read the track name :<- Surprisingly even with unlockables, customization is minimal. Theres no graphics options, Audiosurf 1 alone had selectable "intensity" colours and custom skyboxes. I would prefer if I could choose the track type for a song as proper genre data isn't always available so you get stuck on "Dance" a lot.- There are some rare issues with track generation. For instance, "The Hamster Alliance - Falling Through The Air" has a jump that you can rarely make without boosting. This is a reoccuring issues it seems from the bug report page. It makes tracks that would otherwise be low difficulty have a semi-frustrating aspect to them, cause you have to count jumps and remember which ones are death traps.- There isn't proper leaderboards or statistics. You have to load a song to see the leaderboard. I know for a fact my highest score is about 210k but the game doesn't list that anywhere that I've seen. Also, doesn't have the cool aspect of Audiosurf where you had to try and keep your thrones. I loved that, was a good way to bring you back into the game.TL;DR, super fun singleplayer race/music game, with a degree more customization and a gui overhaul it will really shine.

												Riff Racer is all I could've wanted out of the play-your-own-track subset of the music game genre. Here are a couple of things that the game pulls off really well:You can get plenty of playtime out of it if you have a somewhat sizeable music library sitting in your hard drive. Even if I hadn't picked the game up when it wasn't on sale, I would say it is still very much worth it if you don't want to wait simply for the sheer amount of time you can just spend playing track after track. Useful for people like me who have a good thousand albums sitting around that I haven't gone through, it gives me a bit of motivation to do so, especially considering that the game incentivizes play with in-game currency that you attain from just playing your tracks, used to unlock new cars and paint jobs.The game isn't particularly mechanically dense, but this really works in the game's favor. It's all score based rather than having you drive a closed circuit racetrack. What this essentailly entails is auto-acceleration being on by default and a big focus on manipulating your boost and doing tricks all the while driving clean to attain the best score multipliers, rather than trying to go as fast as you can as per any orthodox racing game. After all, you finish your "track" as soon as the song ends. There aren't that many tricks, but there is a skill involved in it, gathering boost boxes scattered on the track, knowing when to drift, to roll your car instead of just jumping normally, for example.The logic for "track" creation is very slick. I've only had a few songs where a blockade obstacle was placed unfairly, like at the start of a loop where I couldn't see it, but for the most part, it's great and really does pick out set-piece moments in your songs. The difficulty also varies from song to song, though sometimes the hardest songs are the ones you wouldn't expect. I've had drone music play at the highest difficulty and some high-tempo noise rock play on the easiest.The game is simple in its appearance and polygonal car models, but the colorful neon-laden tracks are easy on the eyes and easy to just get lost into a trance to when I try to pull off drift after drift. It's a great visualizer, which is a good thing to have for a game like this. It's never boring to look at, especially since the colors of the tracks vary depending on what genre of music you're playing.Here are a couple of things that the game could improve on in the future (as it is getting updates here and there).The leaderboard and social aspects of the game are just serviceable. You have a player profile page, but there isn't much to see on it. You can see what car you use most, what track you play the most, and that's about it in terms of useful information. Trying to see what tracks a friend has played, for instance, will only yield their most-played track. Along with this, despite using Last.fm as a basis for determining track genres, as far as I know, you don't have the ability to scrobble your tracks. This one's just a minor nitpick of mine, but still, both of these potential features are things Audiosurf had in spades over Riff Racer, and I'd really like to see it worked on.The only game mode you have here is the score-based one. There's no other way to play it, but what the game has to offer is still a lot of fun.Japanese unicode doesn't work and it just comes out as a bunch of question marks :(((Though flawed in some respects (which are just nitpicks on my part), Riff Racer is still, all-in-all, a really solid game. If I could describe it, I'd call it chill. The sort of chill where you just invite someone over and watch shows or movies in the dark while sipping something. Riff Racer's real chill to hang with. It's definitely worth checking out if you're into this type of game.

Here In My Car, I'm Outdritin' 'Em All!Riff Racer = Audiosurf + Forever Drive + UNEXPLAINABLE HOMICIDAL RAGEIf you've played both Audiosurf and Forever Drive, I've pretty much just explained the game to you and if you like those two things just shut up and spend your money.For those unititated, this game is about generating a sort of race track/obstacle course based on your music, and playing through it in order to acheive a high score.  The primary appeal is seeing what kind of ride experience you get based on the song you pick.  Sometimes a track will fit SO perfectly to a song that you'll swear it was handmade and not randomly generated.  Other times you'll have a hard time discerning how your race and the song match up at all, but still find it enjoyable.In the case of Riff Racer, it places emphasis on the racing action and feels very much like a simplistic stunt racing game with pleasant, neon visuals.  The hook here is the fact that when you select a song that no one else out there has yet played, you generate a unique track that is FOREVER YOURS.  So anyone else out there choosing that song will race the track that YOU generated.  It adds a bit of a layer of discovery to the game, as well as interesting emergent competition.See...  This is where I have you tell you I just spent over an hour on a track based on ONE song.  ONE SONG.  Replaying it over and over.  Why...?Well, here I was picking songs that I both liked and thought were just eclectic enough to not have been played.  ...BUT I KEPT RUNNING INTO THIS ONE JAGOFF THAT HAD ALREADY LAID CLAIM TO THEM.  ONE GUY WHO JUST HAPPENED TO LIKE A BUNCH OF DIFFERENT SONGS THAT I LIKE AND WAS TRYING TO STEAL THEM FROM ME HOW DARE YOU SIR?!!?!Naturally, there was only one thing to do...Crush this pretender, cast down his claim to those musical lands, and claim the No. 1 Headband.It seriously sparks some sort of weird obsessive competition when you run into these scenarios.  It's kinda like when two scenesters that each think they are (bandname)'s biggest fan clash, and then the fur really flies!It's strange because otherwise this is one of those games that is chill as it gets.  Cruise through your music (Or even your podcasts!) and enjoy the visuals and cool Tron-like vehicles OR experience keyboard-smashing rage as you get freaky possessive about your special snowflake music!Start your engines if you... Loved the Audiosurf games.  Pretty much a must have for your collections. Like games that are trippy like woah! Have a bizarre need to defend your favorite songs as if they were your waifu.Put it in park if you... Are more so into DDR-style games.  This game is about mastering the drift, not the beats. Need couch co-op and the other plethora of features found in Audiosurf.  This game is currently pretty slim in that regard. Don't really listen to music that much.  Sure this is a stunt racing game, but a lot of the fun is seeing what kind of race track your favorite songs might make.The Bottom LineRiff Racer does what it does very well and with an even coat of polish.  I've dumped about five hours into it mostly in one sitting without even realizing it.  Not many games can claim to have that hold on a person.  It definitely carries that "one more turn" effect, only it's "just one more song".That said, there is definitely room for improvement.  The track visuals really need expanding, as even the different color schemes end up feeling alike to one another.  More game modes, local co-op, more items, powerups, and track terrain would cement this game as a classic.As it stands, it's definitely worth your money as is...  AND STAY THE HELL AWAY FROM MY TRACKS!

The hook here is the fact that when you select a song that no one else out there has yet played, you generate a unique track that is FOREVER YOURS.  So anyone else out there choosing that song will race the track that YOU generated.  It adds a bit of a layer of discovery to the game, as well as interesting emergent competition.See...  This is where I have you tell you I just spent over an hour on a track based on ONE song.  ONE SONG.  Replaying it over and over.  Why...?Well, here I was picking songs that I both liked and thought were just eclectic enough to not have been played.  ...BUT I KEPT RUNNING INTO THIS ONE JAGOFF THAT HAD ALREADY LAID CLAIM TO THEM.  ONE GUY WHO JUST HAPPENED TO LIKE A BUNCH OF DIFFERENT SONGS THAT I LIKE AND WAS TRYING TO STEAL THEM FROM ME HOW DARE YOU SIR?!!?!Naturally, there was only one thing to do...Crush this pretender, cast down his claim to those musical lands, and claim the No. 1 Headband.It seriously sparks some sort of weird obsessive competition when you run into these scenarios.  It's kinda like when two scenesters that each think they are (bandname)'s biggest fan clash, and then the fur really flies!It's strange because otherwise this is one of those games that is chill as it gets.  Cruise through your music (Or even your podcasts!) and enjoy the visuals and cool Tron-like vehicles OR experience keyboard-smashing rage as you get freaky possessive about your special snowflake music!Start your engines if you... Loved the Audiosurf games.  Pretty much a must have for your collections. Like games that are trippy like woah! Have a bizarre need to defend your favorite songs as if they were your waifu.Put it in park if you... Are more so into DDR-style games.  This game is about mastering the drift, not the beats. Need couch co-op and the other plethora of features found in Audiosurf.  This game is currently pretty slim in that regard. Don't really listen to music that much.  Sure this is a stunt racing game, but a lot of the fun is seeing what kind of race track your favorite songs might make.The Bottom LineRiff Racer does what it does very well and with an even coat of polish.  I've dumped about five hours into it mostly in one sitting without even realizing it.  Not many games can claim to have that hold on a person.  It definitely carries that "one more turn" effect, only it's "just one more song".That said, there is definitely room for improvement.  The track visuals really need expanding, as even the different color schemes end up feeling alike to one another.  More game modes, local co-op, more items, powerups, and track terrain would cement this game as a classic.As it stands, it's definitely worth your money as is...  AND STAY THE HELL AWAY FROM MY TRACKS!

There are some great things and some not so great things so I will try to list them all.Great things: -Plenty of cars and paints for the cars.-Visually stunning.-Simple yet challenging. -Track variation is pretty good, although I have found a few songs where most of the song is just drifting back and forth which is quite boring. Sometimes they are too twitchy (Example: pulling out of a drift will slam you into a wall) -Crate and token hitboxes are not consistent either. Sometimes you can drive right next to them and pick them up, other times they won't get picked up.-Lack of control customization and not being able to use mouse/gamepad. You cannot change controls. The controls consist of <- -> [spacebar] and CTRL. There was little tutorial too. I was unsure that I could drift until about my 20th race and then i got a tip saying CTRL was to drift.Overall, considering this is Early access, It is in pretty good shape. There are a few minor things that need to be changed/tweaked/added. But overall, it was worth the money. I would suggest this game to any music lover.

												This is another 'play to your own music' game that revolves around drifting your car through corners, jumping off ramps, and avoiding obstacles. You'll be aiming for the highest score, rather than the fastest time. The drift physics are fun, though maneuvering around walls and over jumps is a little tricky.A song's difficulty is mainly based on its BPM (as opposed to frequencies or volume like you'd see in Beat Hazard and Audiosurf), which results in some cool pulsating backgrounds. But, before you get ready to unleash your speedcore collection on this game, keep in mind that the speed recognition caps at about 200 BPM, and anything over that usually gets wrapped back to 1 star difficulty. The tracks are somewhat dynamic, and loosely follow the intensity of the song as it goes.As for customization, you can unlock cars and different paint jobs, though every car drives in the same way as each other. There are leaderboards, too, and you can drift along with the replay of another driver if there is one. The game also has a nice system of notifying you in the game with its 'news' section when somebody beats your score, and you can go directly to the song from there to reclaim it.Honestly, I'm surprised a game with this premise could be made to begin with. For $10, I'd say the game is worth it. If you want a silly procedurally generated music game where you can drift a car around, this one is good.a

There is a zen-like quality to drifting and chaining back to back corners that would seem to pair itself incredibly well to music based or 'rhythm' gaming. It took only a few minutes to realize that I would not be enjoying this game much at all. Unfortunately the 'drifting' is horrendous. I wasn't expecting too much, something akin to what is in a basic cart racing game. What ruins it is the complete lack of counter-steering. For those not familiar with counter-steering, it is the practice of turning your wheels opposite to the direction you turned to initiate the drift in order to maintain the cars balance to remain drifting instead of simply spinning out. It is the single most crucial aspect of drifting and Riff Racer misses it entirely. So what does this mean in terms of gameplay? It means that being able to guide your car and maintain a drift while sideways is effectively removed. You initiate the drift with a button press and then rely on the angle of your entry point along with your speed to remain drifting while continuing to spam the drift button. If you try to counter steer and maintain your drift the car immediately gains traction and sends you out of the drift and into the wall. It's a mind-boggling design decision that ruined the experience for me almost before it began.

												I like the concept here, but I feel the implementation lacks a little too much for me to give a recommendation.What's good?The idea of racing against the music's cursor. The race track length is equivalent to the song length, and you need to maintain a certain velocity to stay on cue with the song's "now playing" position. It's simple and novel.The music, for the most part. is enjoyable and fits the game well.The ability to use your own music for tracks.Multiple cars to use (and unlock).When you get going really fast and lights on the track pulse to the music. That's when you really feel the flow and is the game's real sweet spot in my opinion.What's not so good?As far as I can tell, the game has just one track style (road texture, skyline, roadside decor, etc.) that it uses over and over again. Every song I picked, even ones auto-generated from my music looked nearly identical. It seems you get a palette swap at best, and even then, a vast majority of the palettes I saw varied from red to pink. To boot, it's very monochromatic (more on that later).The car designs overall are fairly simplistic. They do fit the theme, but it's not like more detail on the cars would clash with the game's visual design.The controls leave me hankering for more precision steering. Given that the game can be played with one hand, it'd be nice to have a button you could press to enter into a fine-precision-steering mode where you didn't steer so acutely. The nature of the race courses rarely call for that, and when they do, it's very tricky to not end up over-correcting.The game's procedural generation of courses is rather bland. As noted before, the style is already repetitively used. Beyond that, there's actually little to do within a course. You collect turbo boost points (which when you've collected enough, you can juice your turbo). You also collect coins to unlock cars in your garage. Outside of those you have blockades, speed boosts, and ramps. The course itself twists, turns, and has gaps for you to jump over. But it all seems like it's a bit sparsely laid out for the sake of avoiding bad combinations that could result from the procedural generation of race courses.I expected to have more of the gameplay and course design attached to some aspect of the music (like ramps right before bass drops or something akin), but there doesn't really seem to be anything like that except for the aforementioned aspect of having pulsing lights to the beat when you're going super fast. I know a feature like this wouldn't be easy, but it would really help create unique and memorable experiences on the race track.Another ramification of the lacking variations in track features and colors is that when you're going turbo speed, the game blurs the camera. Now the game often puts blockades and ramps side-by-side. So with blurred vision, high speeds, and coming about a ramp-blockade combo from blind turns/twists/hills, I found myself often hitting the blockade instead of the ramp in that situation. It's not an insurmountable challenge, but it's an example of where the game's lacking of design and variation creates difficulty where there should be none. Why aren't blockades just given a different color to clearly separate them from ramps?On a few occasions, I ran into poorly generated courses such as ramps right into curves. For a game that's hinging on its procedural generation to create replayability, it really could use a bit of tweaking/polish.I like the game, but there are a few obstacles in the way of me enjoying it for any considerable duration. It feels like it's within reach of being a great title for zoning out to with the right music selections. If racing and/or rhythm games are in your wheelhouse and you are curious what a combination of the two genres would be like, then this is worth a pickup. But in its current state, I wouldn't generally recommend this game to people.

												If you like music runner games, as well as racing games, well then hot damn do I have a game for you!The game seems to be a blend of the arcade-y, drifting-based handling of Ridge Racer, and the intense color pallette/vibing feel of Audiosurf, from what I can tell after about 2 hours of play.On the positive side of the game, it so far has accurately synced up with any song i've thrown at it's engine; the music-generated maps change color and theme depending on the genre of music/intensity of the current moment in the song, with the choices in theme being appropriate thus far; there are many options in the way of what your car looks like, with unlockable rides that you can further customize after purchasing, all using in-game coins earned through playing the game. Kinda sad that has to be a positive side of a game nowadays, huh? Anyways, the actual "racing" itself is done against the pace of the song by way of pace bars you need to try to keep up with to stay synced with the song; the drifting and speed of the game feel incredibly satisfying, with speed boosts placed at areas where the song picks up, or usually, when it goes into a chorus. Also there are spin jumps, which are pretty awesome...when you land them.Now for the negative sides, starting with what I last mentioned. Because the game has spin jumps, it has a sort of physics engine which the car operates on while midair, and while the game encourages you to do spin jumps to score more points, the car can very easily flip and leave you wiping out, resetting your position between the second and third bars. This could just be a case of "i'm bad at the game," but it's rather irritating to lose your 100% sync rate because of something you have little control over; following up on that note, the game has barriers on the track that slow your car, which nine times out of ten, are completely avoidable. But sometimes you get that one time of the ten, where you can't see the barrier coming up because the track is going through a loop, and the song is ridiculously fast, so you get little to no time to react and lose a ton of speed. Again, could just be me being bad, but also again, it's not satisfying to get jipped out of your score because of that; the big complaint i've seen the most, no WMA support. Kinda lame, but it doesn't bother me personally too much, as most of my library is in mp3 format anyways, but I imagine that's a very large glaring issue for many people. Also, channeling my inner TotalBiscuit, the graphics options menu is limited to resolution, and fullscreen on/off, so if you can't run the game as is, you're kind of SOL. Sorry, yo.Overall, i've enjoyed the time i've put into the game, and I would recommend it to people who are fans of games such as Audiosurf, and Ridge Racer.

												Riff Racer is a music based game with the feature to drive on any musical track you put into it. The core of the game is to rack up a large score by pulling off tricks on the tracks generated by your choice of music. Overall it’s fun to both listen and drive on the racetrack, with the game being a unique mix between driving and music games.Any song can be used with Riff Racer to create a specific course to drive on. The gameplay is almost like Audiosurf with the looping, twisty design and the score based objectives. As you drive around the track, jumps, drifts, and boosts can be utilized to increase your score further. Along the track are white boxes to collect, which charges a boost that can be used at any time. At the end of the song, scores are uploaded to a leaderboard to promote competition between players on who can get the highest score for that particular song. The car based gameplay is quite unique, using some arcade driving controls similar to other racing titles. The music does sync up to the track in subtle ways. Fast and slow parts of the song are reflected by how frantic the part of the track is, and complex parts get more obstacles to avoid. Some key points in the current song get synced to obstacles on the track. Each of the certain track features from the song analysis is more loosely timed to the music, and results may vary depending on the songs used. Nevertheless, the driving gameplay offers a fun and relaxed experience to drive to your songs in a way that is timed fairly closely to the music. In addition, the competitive aspect of seeing who can get the highest score on a song is also there for those wanting to show off their skill in playing the game.In an effort to showcase your music as the star of the game, the overall presentation is done in a minimal, yet bright and colorful style. The UI of the game goes for clean white text that’s easy to read on the menus or on the track. The track design is quite flashy and retro in a way, with colors pulsing to the beat and changing based on the action in the song. Riff Racer does more than just analyze songs for their content. The game can also categorize what genre the song is and give the track an appropriate design. This genre detection is purely aesthetic, changing up the design of the track and scenery to better suit the mood. Sound effects are kept to a minimum to keep the music at the forefront of the action, but also to give feedback on the various events happening on the track. Overall it’s a clean and minimal design that’s easy on the eyes, and gets visually more intense in time to the music.As a game that takes cues from other similar music based games and racing games, Riff Racer puts a fun way to drive along to the music. The music synchronization to the track might be looser, but the driving gameplay is great and leaderboards are available to focus on getting high scores. For music and driving fans, Riff Racer brings an excellent experience combining both genres into one game.

 Warning: This game contains flashing lights, Online DRM required for non-bundled songs and framerate cap at 60 FPS lock.Other than that it’s very hard for me to find flaws in Riff Racer, it’s a simple concept bundled with a simple game but it all works together rather well. In case it isn’t obvious this is a racing game that turns any track from your music library into a racing track and places you into a ranking board with other people that have played the same song to measure your driving skills.The way the game calculates this score is kind of ingenious, whenever you’re starting a race a set of 4 lines flash very fast, these lines are actually the multiplier for your score and the least amount of mistakes (i.e. crashing against barriers, failing jumps and not drifting properly) that you get on a track, the most likely you’re going to be 100% “in sync” with the track and get a bigger bonus for doing so at the end. The racing itself feels pretty similar to Hotwheels: Turbo Racing, with the added feature of drifting and with free style tricks on jumps being removed and replaced with tricks based on your ability to line your car properly with ramps. Each car has its own set of stats, however these stats are not defined in the car selection screen and must be learned through playing with each and every single one of them, for instance some cars have better recovery time, some better handling and some have a boost that lasts longer, however these stats are absent when picking a car in the car selection screen.The game offer replay value in the form of unlockables, each car is actually sort of expensive and each car has its own set of skins that go with it that can go up to 25,000 in-game currency with each track giving you as between 200-500 in-game currency if you’re good. The game has absolutely no micro-transactions attached to it so unlocking everything can and will take a while.The one other problem that I do find with this game however is the fact that it can be pretty trial and error at times, due to the random nature of obstacles and jumps you will find yourself doing the same song over and over again until you get it right. But overall I think it’s worth the experience, to me it’s one of the best game to have come out of early access and one of the best games of the year in general, however it does require some amount of patience as the driving can take a while to get used to.
